body:
ps ran across and chatted with @anuraaga about the implicit mirror by google here https://cloud.google.com/container-registry/docs/pulling-cached-images

This is probably good to add to the build, to reduce the chance of someone's pull request that switches our image to a normal one killing our account. However, it won't prevent docker hub pulls as it is only caching what it considers frequently requested images, and we have no control over that.
we can debug the grafana dashboard lack in another PR. thanks for the look @anuraaga!
cc @reta
Closing as no feedback anymore. Please test against latest Zipkin UI and open a new issue if you find the performance to be lacking still.
cc @reta @jeqo as this sort of thing has probably hit you before
CC @adriancole please :)

build break is because a sneaky hidden dependency on docker hub!

```
  E: Failed to fetch https://packagecloud.io/github/git-lfs/ubuntu/dists/bionic/InRelease  402  Payment Required [IP: 54.193.34.251 443]
```

Full output
```

  Hit:1 http://azure.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu bionic InRelease
```

This seems to have executed after the install, so the remedy in the action to swallow exceptions seems ok for now https://github.com/docker-practice/actions-setup-docker/commit/5adf8505b047d11d321093d5b96e291effc0f3c8
That was unexpected ... thanks a lot for digging into it, @adriancole
merging this despite red as the docker install fail is unrelated entirely
Thanks @adriancole !
no prob thanks for putting the effort in here. it is nice to have a partner in crime

@reta this should sort out the glitch

Thx @anuraaga for the advice to keep it simple

the larger image size for arm64 is now fixed (latest zipkin is 2.22.2 though)


![Screen Shot 2020-11-05 at 11 04 22 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64215/98192850-d409e980-1f56-11eb-89bb-671f95d68f22.png)

@adriancole 
Here is the further analysis after your PR for the basic ARM64 support is merged.

After deprecating test for “zipkin-cassandra” docker image, build is terminating for “zipkin-elasticsearch6”, “zipkin-elasticsearch7”, “zipkin-mysql”, “zipkin-kafka” docker images.
These images are available for Linux/AMD64, but not for Linux/ARM64. 
Below are the errored logs in brief:
~~~
2020-11-05 08:46:18:283 [main] ERROR 🐳 [ghcr.io/openzipkin/zipkin-mysql:2.22.1] - Log output from the failed container:
standard_init_linux.go:211: exec user process caused "exec format error"

2020-11-05 08:46:47:658 [main] ERROR 🐳 [ghcr.io/openzipkin/zipkin-elasticsearch7:2.22.1] - Could not start container
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Container did not start correctly.

2020-11-05 08:47:53:809 [main] ERROR 🐳 [ghcr.io/openzipkin/zipkin-elasticsearch6:2.22.1] - Log output from the failed container:
standard_init_linux.go:211: exec user process caused "exec format error"

2020-11-05 08:48:11:617 [main] ERROR 🐳 [ghcr.io/openzipkin/zipkin-kafka:2.22.1] - Could not start container
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Container did not start correctly.
~~~

I have tried building them on a local Linux/ARM64 machine. “zipkin-elasticsearch6”, “zipkin-mysql”, “zipkin-kafka” docker images are building successfully on the ARM64 platform. But “zipkin-elasticsearch7” fails to build on ARM64 because the Dockerfile is downloading an elasticsearch binary (with no jdk) from here  <https://artifacts.elastic.co/downloads/elasticsearch/elasticsearch-oss-7.9.3-no-jdk-linux-x86_64.tar.gz>.  
This binary is not available for the AArch64 platform. However elasticsearch is releasing another binary for AArch64 (with jdk). Please find it here <https://artifacts.elastic.co/downloads/elasticsearch/elasticsearch-7.9.3-linux-aarch64.tar.gz>. 
“Zipkin-elasticsearch7” docker image is successfully getting built for ARM64 after using this binary for elasticsearch on a local ARM64 machine.

It will be really helpful if “zipkin-elasticsearch6”, “zipkin-mysql”, “zipkin-kafka” docker images become available for Linux/ARM64 on the zipkin Docker Hub.
Also, can you please suggest whether we can use elasticsearch binary (with jdk) for building “zipkin-elasticsearch7” docker image? If yes, then I can raise a PR for the ARM64 support in the Dockerfile used to build “zipkin-elasticsearch7” docker image.

@odidev there was a problem in our build identified yesterday on the base layers. Can you re-try (re-pull as we re-pushed them yesterday)?

We don't use the JDK in Elasticsearch anymore so that part might be a distraction, as we are only using jars there correct, not OS binaries.

also feel free to raise a work in progress PR, with GH action or travis config that adds CI.

Ex. I noticed the same thing you did about our images experimenting here

https://travis-ci.org/github/openzipkin/zipkin-reporter-java/builds/741595257

Then I put a sanity check in the travis config as initially our JRE as you mentioned was messed up.

Then I added this to the base image to fix the JRE https://github.com/openzipkin/docker-java/commit/8a47a19314bf02e60dadda0fa621d920431adf62

Then you notice in the above logs the java image works, but our reporter build runs, but still fails on rabbit, which I'll note in another issue (fail is silently as we use a assumption condition, but there's stuff in the logs)

Our code uses this image: `ghcr.io/openzipkin/rabbitmq-management-alpine:latest` which we mirrored from https://hub.docker.com/layers/rabbitmq/library/rabbitmq/3.8.9-management-alpine, but even switching to that gives an error in arm64

```
at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:834)

10:13:07.175 [main] ERROR o.t.utility.ResourceReaper - Timed out waiting for Ryuk container to start. Ryuk's logs:

standard_init_linux.go:211: exec user process caused "exec format error"
```

I wonder if rabbit's image is busted, or if somehow it is being misinterpreted. Only thing I notice is that the arch mentioned here is linux/arm64/v8 not linux/arm64, but then again travis slaves are v8. 

cc @odidev
arm64 won't work since we don't have ARM support in Ryuk (yet). You can disable it, but some other images may fail too

@adriancole 

Thank you for releasing ARM64 docker images for “zipkin-mysql”, “zipkin-kafka”, “zipkin-elasticsearch6” and “zipkin-elasticsearch7”.
I have again forked zipkin and built it for arm64-graviton2 using Travis utility. Issues related to openzipkin docker images are now resolved. But the ARM64 job is terminating to start ryuk containers. Please find the error logs below:
~~~
2020-11-06 06:29:08:460 [testcontainers-ryuk] WARN org.testcontainers.utility.ResourceReaper - Can not connect to Ryuk at localhost:32769

2020-11-06 06:29:08:625 [main] ERROR org.testcontainers.utility.ResourceReaper - Timed out waiting for Ryuk container to start. Ryuk's logs:
standard_init_linux.go:211: exec user process caused "exec format error"
~~~

With reference to the comment in the issue <https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/3279#issuecomment-722937650>,  RYUK does not contain ARM64 support:
>> arm64 won't work since we don't have ARM support in Ryuk (yet). You can disable it, but some other images may fail too

I have disabled RYUK as below:
~~~
export TESTCONTAINERS_RYUK_DISABLED=true
~~~
After disabling, ryuk does not bother anymore in arm64 logs, and both ARM64 and AMD64 jobs reach a common point, where both fail to decrypt gpg passphrase. Here are the error logs:
~~~
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-gpg-plugin:1.6:sign (sign-artifacts) on project zipkin-parent: Unable to decrypt gpg passphrase: org.sonatype.plexus.components.sec.dispatcher.SecDispatcherException: java.io.FileNotFoundException: /home/travis/.m2/settings-security.xml (No such file or directory) -> [Help 1]
~~~
Please find the related error jobs here : <https://travis-ci.com/github/odidev/zipkin/jobs/429516679#L5780>

And when I skip maven-gpg-plugin in my forked repo, then both the jobs fail to deploy the artifacts, which is obvious because I do not possess the permissions for the deployment. Please find the error logs:
~~~
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.sonatype.plugins:nexus-staging-maven-plugin:1.6.8:deploy (injected-nexus-deploy) on project zipkin-server: Failed to deploy artifacts: Could not transfer artifact io.zipkin.zipkin2:zipkin:jar:2.22.3-20201106.071057-6 from/to ossrh (https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/snapshots): Transfer failed for https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/snapshots/io/zipkin/zipkin2/zipkin/2.22.3-SNAPSHOT/zipkin-2.22.3-20201106.071057-6.jar 401 Unauthorized -> [Help 1]
~~~
Please find the related error jobs here : <https://travis-ci.com/github/odidev/zipkin/jobs/429518136#L8423>

Please find my analysis below:

1. .travis.yml file : <https://github.com/odidev/zipkin/blob/master/.travis.yml#L74>
2. Travis-CI jobs : <https://travis-ci.com/github/odidev/zipkin/builds/198692829>

If you think we can disable the ryuk containers, then I will raise the PR with arm64-graviton2 jobs in the Travis. ‘arm64-graviton2’ makes use of a VM with dist: focal, and not Lxd containers.
Please share your opinion on this.

Thanks for the research and looks good. I visually verified that the IT* for collector and storage are not skipping 👍 Notably, we also have a re-pushed an image for rabbit, and it is good to know that worked, too.

If we are using a special-cased matrix, maybe we should just run `./mvnw verify -nsu -DskipActuator` instead of the publish script, as we wouldn't want to dual-publish anyway. This will avoid any accidents.

ex. keeping comments like this:
```
  # verify runs both tests and integration tests (Docker tests included)
  # -DskipActuator ensures no tests rely on the actuator library
  ./mvnw verify -nsu -DskipActuator
```

> If you think we can disable the ryuk containers, then I will raise the PR with arm64-graviton2 jobs in the Travis.

Maybe link https://github.com/testcontainers/moby-ryuk/issues/15 in the comments and also see if you can use `~/.testcontainers.properties` Also good to note https://github.com/testcontainers/moby-ryuk/issues/16 as I forgot about ryuk (it is yet another docker hub pull until this is resolved)

> ‘arm64-graviton2’ makes use of a VM with dist: focal, and not Lxd containers.

I think we'd want to use arm64, not graviton in our build. We are running off https://travis-ci.org/ and our goal is arm64, not specifically using graviton to do this. If we ever migrate to travis.com it should be decoupled from using arm (ex move to arm then maybe migrate). Migrating yet another build tool is probably too much right now, as personally I've spent the last entire month on the build and various pro/cons discussions.. Don't really want to research and champion another cause.

Despite the changes here being something I could easily pop into the build now, definitely prefer you doing the honors, since you did all the research. Much appreciated!

If following this, you'd like to make our github integrated docker tests a build matrix of arm64 that would be cool, as that actually tests the zipkin images we build continue to work (before we release them).
fyi https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-reporter-java/pull/192

Thanks for offering this @jufab! We've run into problems with translations in the past due to lack of participation after first merge. Can you help find 2 other french-speaking folks to review this and possibly help maintain this? cc @fedj
just sent a tweet on our account to help rally support also

and https://github.com/openzipkin/brave/pull/1277

I'll make the testcontainers changes here directly independent of arm64 as I didn't realize we were pulling images until this topic.

ack it was indeed ryuk. We have a workaround here. there's no problem with the rabbitmq image we are using, though it would be nice to have an official one not in docker.io https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3290
#3290 will make finishing this up easy I think. go for it when ready
verified visually that all integration tests that use docker in fact ran (weren't skipped)

No problem @adriancole 
I used your post on Tweeter to find other french people 👍

@ImFlog Thanks for your review, I pushed new version.
Just I have no better word than "section"... :D

hmm regardless of independent topic or not, I missed the memo. It looks like Travis is shutting down .org https://mailchi.mp/3d439eeb1098/travis-ciorg-is-moving-to-travis-cicom so might as well get in front of this (like it or not!) cc @openzipkin/core 

@odidev I'll transfer this repo and the others to travis-ci.com

@odidev so I noticed you said "‘arm64-graviton2’ makes use of a VM with dist: focal, and not Lxd containers."

I noticed that setting up an LXD matrix job with arm64-graviton2 fails unexpectedly (boot cycling), but it isn't documented as unsupported either.. https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/reference/overview/

Is there some document somewhere that notes arm64-graviton2 as LXD only? The boot time is a bigger deal in most of our projects vs execution speed, as boot delays are often several minutes and execution times often a minute or two.

cc @anuraaga

@adriancole 
I have raised the PR to add the ARM64 job to Travis-CI.
>> I noticed that setting up an LXD matrix job with arm64-graviton2 fails unexpectedly (boot cycling), but it isn't documented as unsupported either.. https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/reference/overview/

Graviton is available for travis.com only, not travis.org. Graviton can be used with both LXD and VM. With ‘virt: vm’, we can only specify ‘dist: focal’; and ‘virt: lxd’ goes with these three dist: ‘focal’, ‘xenial’, ‘bionic’.

**Ex: ‘with VM’**
~~~    
virt: vm
group: edge
arch: arm64-graviton2
os: linux
dist: focal
~~~


**Ex: ‘with LXD’**
~~~    
virt: lxd
group: edge
arch: arm64-graviton2
os: linux
dist: focal    // or ‘dist: bionic’ or ‘dist: xenial’
~~~

note: It has been over 2 weeks and no one has thumbs upped my comment or replied persistently. Zipkin is a volunteer community and we only add features people will use as they cost work and attention. Our time to implement and support this will be far more effort than the time requested to even thumbs up or reply if EUREKA_URL will work. If no one replies in the next week, I'll close out the ticket and cite this next time asked.

@odidev thanks I'll copy you on any next fail.. it was just odd because I tried to setup a matrix and it was flipping out (graviton never passed it just kept cycling on boot). I *didn't* add `group: edge` though
@adriancole please add this to zipkin server. We are heavy on eureka server and this will help us a lot.
@asif-rashid thanks for the feedback. If the only configuration for the server was `EUREKA_URL` and the instance ID set to "zipkin-server" or simply "zipkin" would this be good enough for your site?

PS I've tried in a couple different repos, and LXD graviton is on a reboot cycle.. we can try again later in the year or if you want to raise an issue with them, go ahead..

Ex. from brave-cassandra
```diff
diff --git a/.travis.yml b/.travis.yml
index f8c9232..8b3d929 100644
--- a/.travis.yml
+++ b/.travis.yml
@@ -1,11 +1,10 @@
 # Run `travis lint` when changing this file to avoid breaking the build.
 
 # See https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/reference/overview/#for-a-particular-travisyml-configuration
-arch: arm64-graviton2 # Use AWS Graviton2
-group: edge           # Required with arm64-graviton2 per https://blog.travis-ci.com/2020-09-11-arm-on-aws
-virt: lxd             # LXD containers where possible as they boot much faster than full VMs
-os: linux             # required for arch different than amd64
-dist: focal           # newest available distribution
+arch: arm64 # Can't use arm64-graviton2 as it cycles on boot as of 2020-11-02
+virt: lxd   # LXD containers where possible as they boot much faster than full VMs
+os: linux   # required for arch different than amd64
+dist: focal # newest available distribution
 
 # license-maven-plugin needs the full history to generate copyright year range. Ex. 2013-2020
 # Don't do a shallow clone, as it interferes with this.
```

![looper](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64215/98610927-c6c07680-232b-11eb-939f-df4a6abeb53a.gif)
Yes, this should work for us.

incidentally, left alone long enough the graviton2 LXD build eventually booted.. however, it took so long it is still not a viable configuration.. perhaps there aren't that many free nodes available. anyway it is good to know it is possible, even if not yet viable, to use graviton2 LXD

EOF!

no thanks on this one. This calls attention to that the default VM isn't lxd which is the primary reason why we are using arm64 instead of amd64. Prefer to be explicit vs make assumptions that are only true when you hold arm64 constant.

https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/reference/overview/

ps if you prefer to move the rationale into the job definition, that's also fine. ex move lxd's comment into where arm64 is defined.

However we do things, it is important for folks who aren't familiar with this stuff to know quickly the tradeoffs made. I think almost no one has had time to track the arm64 effort so want their life easiest when they decide to jump in and do something, to understand what's going on and not accidentally subvert something. That's primarily the reason for all these comments which were explicitly written.. for the many folks who aren't able to watch 10 changes per day while kinks are sorted out.

Setting ‘virt: lxd’ globally will also set the lxd environment for the AMD64 job, which is generally Full VM, as discussed here <https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/reference/overview/#which-one-do-i-use>. For Ubuntu Focal 20.04:  

arch: amd64: full VM only, default option
arch: arm64: LXD only
arch: arm64-graviton2: LXD and full VM
arch: ppc64le: LXD only
arch: s390x: LXD only

Hence, it is taking much time in the boot/queue state. 
We can mention ‘virt: lxd’ within the arm64 job itself. This would not affect the AMD64 build.

gotcha.. feel free to move that to the arm64 definition.

Also, if you want, give arm64 graviton another try. I just had a support email with travis about a different issue, but was plan related. My guess is graviton could have been affected by that, and so it might not cycle anymore. It would be cool for you to put  the PR in that actually puts graviton into use!
feel free to re-use this PR or make a new one. I'm watching something for a bit but will check back before I turn in for the night.

raised a couple issues about the skipped tests

* #3295 kafka isn't running but I don't think it is related
* #3296 cassandra isn't running on arm64 - We need to fix the JRE if that's the problem. Then, we'll need to add details about the upstream issue in Cassandra if still relevant. This one is rather important to solve as this image is also used in zipkin-dependencies.. I'll look into it.

Thanks again for the help!
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3297 should fix this
I see three independent folks interested in this besides me, as well two who can help maintain this. Let's do it!
Note: I'm leaving JRE 1.8 as since after cassandra 3.11.3, you can't run it anymore due to use of sun.misc
@jorgheymans @making either of you have some time to kill this? The output is from the docker image.. I've not checked the exec jar (or slim)
Can you clarify what the problem is?
sorry in the description, there are warnings and errors which seem to be related to the logo format and code involved in colorizing..

in our zipkin-server-shared.yml we have

```
logging:
  pattern:
    level: "%clr(%5p) %clr([%X{traceId}/%X{spanId}]){yellow}"
```

I guess maybe some type drifted in recent boot or our usage of it.

`docker run --rm ghcr.io/openzipkin/zipkin:2.22.1` works without these errors...

Here's what's in that ...
```bash
$ docker run --rm -it --entrypoint /bin/sh  ghcr.io/openzipkin/zipkin:2.22.1
~ $ find BOOT-INF/lib/*log*
BOOT-INF/lib/log4j-api-2.13.3.jar
BOOT-INF/lib/log4j-core-2.13.3.jar
BOOT-INF/lib/log4j-jul-2.13.3.jar
BOOT-INF/lib/log4j-slf4j-impl-2.13.3.jar
BOOT-INF/lib/spring-boot-starter-log4j2-2.3.4.RELEASE.jar
```

vs 2.22.2 ... here's what's in that ...
```bash
$ docker run --rm -it --entrypoint /bin/sh  ghcr.io/openzipkin/zipkin:2.22.2
~ $ find BOOT-INF/lib/*log*
BOOT-INF/lib/log4j-api-2.13.3.jar
BOOT-INF/lib/log4j-core-2.13.3.jar
BOOT-INF/lib/log4j-jul-2.13.3.jar
BOOT-INF/lib/log4j-slf4j-impl-2.13.3.jar
BOOT-INF/lib/spring-boot-starter-log4j2-2.3.5.RELEASE.jar
```
ran this with the docker-compose example to show that it is creating a working schema (ENSURE_SCHEMA is false there)

@openzipkin/core Travis is cut off due to a migration problem. I missed the fine print when migrated from travis-ci.org -> .com trying to get graviton up for @odidev... we have to explicitly apply to be OSS (similar to the application I filed the other day for Docker Hub). What happened was, I used up my personal credits which might replenish tomorrow I guess... I emailed their support to give us a big budget and sorry about the problem.

The build here was ironically only red on GH actions, which is now green, so I'll merge, though it won't cut an image because Travis is supposed to do that. I'll ping back here when travis gets back to me about the OSS credit thing.

That feature has been around at least since 5.0 (though I suspect longer).

The concept does not apply to the new data streams, but you aren't using those yet (I assume).

And the new `allow_auto_create` allows overriding it with the v2 templates, but any templates should be under your control so it's up to you — otherwise I would expect a lot of weird things to happen if the wrong templates are being applied.
hmm maybe I'm misunderstanding. We intentionally create templates, so then I think we would explicitly not want "allow_auto_create", then, based on your description.

Sorry, for commenting on an old issue.  Just encountered an issue with dots in tag names but won't go into that here.  

I wonder if it's worth adopting an escaping strategy?  E.g. URL encoding + encode the periods (which isn't the normal way with URL encoding).  I.e. replace "." with "%2E".  That way you'd always be able to get back the original tag name but you could avoid any issues with names that conflict with Elasticsearch.

1. One common approach (for example in the Beats) is to "dedot" tags — replacing dots with underscores. Though if you have some hierarchy with dots, the underscores might cause confusion, so I would consider it more of a hack than a solution.
2. Alternatively the [flattened field type](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/flattened.html) might be an interesting alternative: It doesn't create a mapping for that field and thus avoids the issue of having a mapping collision with `foo` and `foo.bar` (`foo` cannot be a concrete type and an object at the same time) — @msmsimondean I assume that's the problem you ran into. Otherwise flattened behaves pretty much like a keyword field, so it should be a good match for tags. The downside is that it is not available on AWS ES, since it's a free Basic feature.

Sorry if I was unclear — trying to juggle too many things in parallel...

`allow_auto_create` only applies to v2 templates, but I think Zipkin is only using v1 (legacy) templates, right?
So with v1, if you only explicitly create the template but not the indices, `auto_create_index: false` is a problem. Either you'd need to keep it at `true` (the default) or switch it to a pattern that allows the Zipkin indices to be created automatically. Unless you can create all Zipkin indices explicitly with a `PUT zipkin-index-of-the-day`.

Once you switch over to v2 templates, `allow_auto_create` in the template sounds like the better solution. Though with things still being a bit in motion (`allow_auto_create` is IMO only coming in Elasticsearch 7.11), it might make sense to wait until we're getting closer to 8.0 to look at the bigger / more complete picture?

As to the original question around documentation: It might make sense to document that `action.auto_create_index: false` creates a problem the Zipkin tries to create indices.

> ```
> logging:
>  pattern:
>    level: "%clr(%5p) %clr([%X{traceId}/%X{spanId}]){yellow}"
> ```

I have confirmed that this works with vanilla Spring 2.3.4 but not with 2.3.5+.
I'll dig into it more.

probably this is a related commit
https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/commit/f6492cd0c078f247fb094a278dbf4ae3e49d810f

Prior to Spring 2.3.5, `logging.pattern.level` simply does not seem to be respected with log4j2.

You can see the difference between `spring-boot-starter-log4j2` and `spring-boot-starter-logging`.

`spring-boot-starter-log4j2`

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/106908/99264245-8dc05e80-2863-11eb-8690-c6ef12358aa5.png)

`spring-boot-starter-logging`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/106908/99264308-a2045b80-2863-11eb-8542-c41dff0fed68.png)
in Log4J2, `%clr{%5p}` is correct instead of `%clr(%5p)`

Not right now, I think I mentioned this once on gitter and I don't really remember where we encountered this.

Thanks for raising the issue @BbolroC  I'll make comments and **bold** questions for you. Firstly, I noticed you raised some PRs so assume you are willing to help with this. However, until others mention it, we have to assume no-one else is familiar with this arch. **Are you willing to be pinged in the future about s390x?**

We have a "rule of three" policy here on things that add maintenance costs to the project. Sometimes vendors add their own hardware options before clients request them, but in volunteer OSS, we don't do the "if you build it, they will come" as sometimes.. they don't come and we are stuck with the tech debt, and no one to ask if it was ever used. You mentioned this is for clients who have Z hardware. **Can you have a couple users comment directly on this issue that they will use this?** 

Some notes s390x:
 * our [base image](https://github.com/openzipkin/docker-alpine) will likely work https://pkgs.alpinelinux.org/packages?name=openjdk15&branch=edge
 * automatically downloading NPM cross-platform won't work due to missing musl+390x [here](https://nodejs.org/dist/v14.15.1/)
   * musl isn't [here](https://unofficial-builds.nodejs.org/download/release/v14.15.1/) either
   * installing NPM directly should work the same as arm64 though https://pkgs.alpinelinux.org/packages?name=nodejs-current
* integration tests will have similar problems to arm64 #3166 as we build docker images for tests. Notably Cassandra was a problem on arm64 and while isn't officially supported still, it happens to work at the moment.

travis recently cut services significantly and we can't even test arm64 anymore. We have to switch to GH actions which only has x86. In the past arm64 images failed and no one knew it and it cost me personally a lot of time. **Do you know a free CI that can boot a s390x to ensure it actually works? (without use of an emulator)**

cc @openzipkin/core just in case any of you have stake in s390x and can comment back
cc @odidev not that you use s390x, but just in case as I know you have a lot of experience after the arm64 thing

one problem we have is that s390x is behind on JDK 11 and 15

ex https://pkgs.alpinelinux.org/packages?name=openjdk11&branch=edge

amd64 and aarch64 is 11.0.9_p11-r0
s390x is 11.0.8_p10-r0

we keep a uniform version, that they are published mutually exclusive wrt patch this makes it impossible to use these packages

Main thing here is that the build-bin/*/** files will be common across projects. It was very hard to make them work for everything, but it is now the case. As mentioned in the README, files directly in build-bin/ are project specific, while directories like build-bin/docker are not.
